title: 103_hr1317
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Franchise Data and Public Information Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Congress finds a lack of reliable statistical information on franchise businesses despite their growing importance in the American marketplace. The Act aims to provide accurate statistical information about franchising to the public, highlighting the risks associated with investing in franchise businesses due to misleading data and promotional material. The Act aims to provide comprehensive statistical information about franchising to the public, ensuring transparency and reliability in franchise practices for prospective investors. The Act aims to provide comprehensive statistical information about franchising to the public, ensuring transparency and reliability in franchise practices for prospective investors. SEC. 3. NATIONAL FILING AND DATA COLLECTION. All individuals or entities selling franchises must file a copy of the franchise disclosure document with the Commerce Department. The document must be the most recent version incorporating current information as of the franchisor's latest fiscal year. The franchise disclosure document must be the most recent version reflecting the franchisor's latest fiscal year. It should be the most restrictive version provided to prospective franchisees, filed annually with the Commerce Department, and made available to Congress and other federal agencies upon request. It is illegal for franchisors to falsely claim that disclosure documents have been reviewed or approved by the Commerce Department or any other Federal agency. The Commerce Department will establish procedures for collecting and publishing statistical information on franchise ownership and practices within 240 days of the enactment of this section. The principal source of information will be disclosure documents filed annually under subsection (a). The Commerce Department will collect statistical information on franchise ownership and practices annually, including categories like total numbers of franchisors, types of franchise businesses, turnover in ownership, and franchise failures. They will consult with various organizations to identify additional categories for data analysis. The Commerce Department will collect statistical information on franchise ownership annually, including data from disclosure materials and public sources. They will also conduct periodic questionnaires to supplement information in disclosure documents. The Commerce Department will publish a report on franchise ownership and national franchising practices, based on information collected annually from disclosure materials, public sources, and periodic questionnaires. The Commerce Department will publish a report on franchise ownership and national franchising practices, based on information collected annually. The report will be transmitted to Congress and made public through the Superintendent of Documents. SEC. 4. CENSUS DATA ON FRANCHISE BUSINESSES. The Bureau of the Census will include statistical information on franchise businesses in its Business Census, consult with the Federal Trade Commission to identify these businesses, and submit a report within 280 days of enactment. The Bureau of Census will include statistical information on franchise businesses in the Business Census and submit a report to Congress within 280 days of enactment. The Secretary of Commerce is authorized to create rules and regulations to implement the Act, including fees for filing requirements. Definitions are also provided in the Act. The Act defines key terms related to franchising, such as "advertisement," "disclosure document," and "franchise." It outlines what constitutes an advertisement and disclosure document, as well as the criteria for a franchise agreement. The Act defines key terms related to franchising, such as "advertisement," "disclosure document," and "franchise." It outlines criteria for a franchise agreement, including the creation of a commercial relationship where a franchisor grants a franchisee the right to sell goods or services associated with the franchisor's trademark. The franchisor must establish quality standards for goods or services offered by the franchisee, who must operate under the franchisor's trademark. The franchisor also imparts knowledge and expertise to the franchisee. The franchisor imparts knowledge, expertise, and controls over the franchisee's method of operation. The term "franchisee" refers to a person granted a franchise, where the franchisee is required to make payments or commitments to the franchisor. This includes subfranchises or any commercial relationships based on representations that certain criteria will be met. The term "franchisee" refers to a person granted a franchise, while a "franchisor" is the entity granting the franchise. A "person" can be a natural person or a legal entity. A "subfranchise" is a contract where a person pays a franchisor for the right to sell franchises or provide goods/services to franchisees.
